parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build the CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find.

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand the task. Please provide the first archaeology or historical studies-related software tool you would like me to research.

Understood. I will conduct a thorough search for mentions of the software tool 'ArchEd' in archaeology and historical studies. I will document each source systematically in a CSV format, including the year, citation, URL, and any notes on data provenance or uncertainties. This will include scholarly literature, blog posts, software repositories, and any other credible mentions from 1995 onward. I will notify you once the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a thorough search for mentions of the software tool 'ArchEd' in archaeology and historical studies. I will document each source systematically in a CSV format, including the year, citation, URL, and any notes on data provenance or uncertainties. This will include scholarly literature, blog posts, software repositories, and any other credible mentions from 1995 onward. I will notify you once the research is complete.","title":"Evidence Collection for ArchEd Archaeology Tool","prompt":"Conduct a systematic search for mentions of the archaeology and historical studies-related software tool 'ArchEd' from 1995 onwards. 

For each mention found, document the following in a quoted CSV format:

- "Tool": Consistently use 'ArchEd' as the tool name.
- "Year": Extract the publication year of the source or use 'n.d.' if no date is found.
- "Source": Provide a citation or the domain and page title.
- "URL": Include the direct URL to the source.
- "AI Notes": Document any concerns, uncertainties, or comments on the quality or provenance of the data.

Ensure a meticulous approach by:
- Searching through scholarly literature, blog posts, about pages, software repositories, and any other credible sources.
- Checking version control repositories for public code commits with timestamps.
- Recording a separate entry for each mention found in different years.
- Expanding searches by ±1 year from any identified publication dates.
- Avoiding extrapolation of dates—only include dates explicitly stated in sources.

Take the necessary time to examine all available search results and web pages to ensure comprehensive and epistemologically sound research."}

metadata.async_task_title: Evidence Collection for ArchEd Archaeology Tool
metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a systematic search for mentions of the archaeology and historical studies-related software tool 'ArchEd' from 1995 onwards. 

For each mention found, document the following in a quoted CSV format:

- "Tool": Consistently use 'ArchEd' as the tool name.
- "Year": Extract the publication year of the source or use 'n.d.' if no date is found.
- "Source": Provide a citation or the domain and page title.
- "URL": Include the direct URL to the source.
- "AI Notes": Document any concerns, uncertainties, or comments on the quality or provenance of the data.

Ensure a meticulous approach by:
- Searching through scholarly literature, blog posts, about pages, software repositories, and any other credible sources.
- Checking version control repositories for public code commits with timestamps.
- Recording a separate entry for each mention found in different years.
- Expanding searches by ±1 year from any identified publication dates.
- Avoiding extrapolation of dates—only include dates explicitly stated in sources.

Take the necessary time to examine all available search results and web pages to ensure comprehensive and epistemologically sound research.

async_task_status_messages.initial: Evidence Collection for ArchEd Archaeology Tool

parts:
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"  
"ArchEd","1998","Graph Drawing 1997 conference (LNCS vol. 1353)【27†L615-L618】","https://doi.org/10.1007/3-540-63938-1_72","Early reference to ArchEd (noted as “ArchE”) presented by its developers; credible conference paper in a computer science proceedings."  
"ArchEd","2000","Internet Archaeology Issue 8 – Review of ArchEd and Stratigraph【8†L16-L24】","https://intarch.ac.uk/journal/issue8/reviews/rains.html","Peer-reviewed journal review of ArchEd; reliable source detailing the tool’s functionality and context."  
"ArchEd","2002","Mutzel et al. 2002 in Arch\u00e4ologie und Computer Workshop 6【22†L19-L23】","https://journals.openedition.org/cybergeo/25233?lang=en","Conference proceedings (published on CD-ROM) with the primary description of ArchEd by its creators; accessible via citation references (original medium not online)."  
"ArchEd","2008","TU Wien – *The Harris Matrix Composer: A New Tool to Manage...*【38†L1-L4】","https://www.cg.tuwien.ac.at/research/publications/2008/TRA08/TRA08-paper.pdf","Academic paper noting ArchEd’s last update (v1.4 in 2004) and that development ceased thereafter; credible, but information is second-hand (context of a new tool superseding ArchEd)."  
"ArchEd","2019","Arqueolog\u00eda y Software Libre (blog) – “Requiem por ArchEd”【46†L59-L67】","https://arqueologia.home.blog/2019/02/19/arched-harris-matrix/","Informal blog post reflecting on ArchEd’s legacy; confirms the tool’s origins at Max Planck Institute and notes its availability (anecdotal but knowledgeable perspective, given lack of official site)."#

metadata.text: The last version of ArchEd (v1.4) was released in 2004 and since then development has been frozen. We first considered building upon ArchEd and implementing missing features. But analysis of the requirements convinced us that it is better to

metadata.title: Requiem por ArchEd – Arqueología y Software Libre
metadata.text: ArchEd es un programa para la visualización de la Harris Matrix de las intervenciones arqueológicas. Su uso, relativamente sencillo consiste en definir una serie de unidades estratigráficas y la relación que existe entre ellas. Fue creado en el Max Planck Institut für Informatik at Saarbrücken. En la actualidad algunos de las webs donde se alojaba este programa ya no existen, únicamente lo he podido localizar en esta dirección.
